thread.title: Holidays away worth year round sacrifices for Australian families
thread.title_full: Holidays away worth year round sacrifices for Australian families

author: Robyn Ironside National Travel Writer
title: Holidays away worth year round sacrifices for Australian families
text:
EXCLUSIVE
FAMILIES are paring down their lifestyles in every way they can in order to have the treat they cherish the most — a family holiday.
New research released today by Expedia.com.au shows a large proportion of parents rate holidays as much of a budget priority as the mortgage, for the purpose of “spending time together”.
Forty-two per cent of the study group said that was the main motivation for a family holiday , followed by escaping work (17 per cent) and introducing the kids to new places and broadening their horizons (14 per cent).
THE PARADISE COUNTRY WITH OVER 7000 ISLANDS
‘BEST PIECE OF TRAVEL ADVICE I’VE RECEIVED’ Together time ... Jasmine and Aaron Boothey and children Blair, 4, and Hamish, 19 months, believe in making sacrifices to afford family holidays. Picture: Mark Brake / News Corp Australia Source: News Corp Australia
Despite the weaker Australian dollar, a third of the 1016 parents surveyed said they were still planning to holiday overseas but would look for a more affordable destination.
When choosing where to go, the cost of accommodation was the biggest consideration, followed by the price of flights and the availability of package deals.
Sydney mother-of-four Despina Lord said she was always on the lookout for ‘two-for-one’ deals and hotels that provided a second room for kids at a reduced price.
“To help us reach our budget goals we try and sacrifice on things like eating out, or going to the movies in order to put the money aside,” said Ms Lord.
“At the moment our overseas holiday dream is just that — a dream, but we are looking at cheaper locations where the exchange rate shouldn’t be an issue like South East Asia.”
COMMENT BELOW: Where are hoping to go on holiday and why? Beach baby ... Jeremy and Annabelle White on holidays at Noosa Main Beach. Picture: Supplied. Source: Supplied
South Australia’s Jasmine Boothey said family holidays were as important to her and husband Aaron as paying off the mortgage in terms of budget commitments.
“We set aside a certain amount in our budget to fund our holidays — we just make it a priority,” said Ms Boothey, a mother of two.
“We tend to take two holidays a year, one domestic and one overseas and we happily go without some things such as eating out regularly.”
Olivia White of Melbourne, said her family was fortunate they could holiday outside of peak periods and take advantage of last minute deals.
“My daughter isn’t in school so we’re not locked into those school holiday times,” said Ms White.
“Basically I’m always looking for the best deal — I’ve been able to book flights for just $10. I wouldn’t want to spend more than $2000 on flights and accommodation (for three people).” Family fun ... Sydney’s Samantha Kirton and daughter Skye live simply so they can get away regularly. Picture: Supplied. Source: Supplied
Cairns’ mother Alyce Haack said she had always enjoyed travelling and saw no reason to stop when daughter Riley came along 18-months ago.
“We live a minimalist lifestyle with most of my purchases being out of necessity not want,” said Ms Haack.
“I do not buy junk for decorating my house or knick knacks, and have a budget in mind when I choose our next holiday.”
Already mother and daughter have travelled to Hobart, Melbourne, Mission Beach, Townsville and Cape Tribulation.
“I can’t wait to take Riley to New York when she is old enough to appreciate it. But for now, anything close to nature is definitely fun and exciting,” she said. Little traveller ... Alyce and Riley Haack treasure family holidays. Picture: Supplied. Source: Supplied
Samantha and Ivan Kirton, of Sylvania in Sydney’s south, said buying groceries in bulk, having low cost weekends and purchasing gifts online helped them put aside $10,000 a year for travel.
“We do’t make outlandish purchases that we can’t afford, we have a minimalist mindset and spend a good deal of time together outdoors,” said Ms Kirton
Expedia.com.au travel expert Kelly Cull said packaging flights and hotels together could provide significant savings for families of around $200.
“As a result we are seeing strong demand for package holidays to popular holiday hot spots including Rome and Auckland (up 33 per cent), New York (up 17 per cent) and Bali (11 per cent,” said Ms Cull.
